prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: g7 3 mm continuum emission in postAGB objects to search for very large grains

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen each of the fours SPWs with the widest bandpass available (1875 MHz), and the lowest spectral resolution (as we are only interested in continuum detection), avoiding frequency overlaps and maximizing sensitivity. We have carefully chosen center frequencies in each of the bands 3, 6, and 7 in order to minimize overlap of the bandpass with telluric lines. The frequency ranges covered in bands 3, 6, and 7 are 90-105, 223-243, and 336-351 GHz.

Our existing observations of a small sample of pAGB sources show that the continuum emission is likely to be compact (<~1"). But we do not know the extent or the structure of the emitting region on smaller scales. There are several possibilities - e.g., the emission could be confined to an unresolved structure at the highest resolution (e.g. a ~100 AU disk); or it could be an extended equatorial torus structure (~1000-2000 AU at typical distance of 2 kpc, i.e., 0.5"-1" in size) as seen in scattered light in HST images of PPNe, or it could be a combination of such a structure and emission from dense regions at the base of the bipolar lobes.
We aim to resolve the mm-wave continuum emission if its size is greater than the beam size, i.e., >0.35" (and provide significant constraints for models if it is smaller). Our choice of an angular resolution of 0.35" (about 1000 AU at 3 kpc) has been made in order to allow for the possibility to distinguish between the relatively compact disks expected in dpAGB objects (<1000 AU) and the more extended ones of size ~1000-2000 AU expected for PPNe, at a typical distance of 3 kpc. Since our target list includes many sources significantly brighter than the threshold flux values for inclusion in the list, for these we expect to obtain high dynamic range images at the highest frequency, that will be able to distinguish between the above possibilities.

For this band (band 3), our required sensitivity is 0.05 mJy/beam (see full explanation for all bands below).
We require fairly short on-source integration times per source(about 3.5 min, 0.5 min, 0.5 min) for bands 3, 6, and 7, respectively), and the total observing times are dominated by the calibration and pointing sequence, which requires about 25-35 min per wavelength band. We require 1-sigma sensitivities of 0.05, 0.4, 1.0 mJy/beam in Bands 3, 6, 7 (at frequencies of about 90-105, 223-243, and 336-351 GHz), which will provide high signal-to-noise (S/N) for all of our sources in each band. In the cover sheet, the fluxes provided for each source are NOT the expected fluxes, but simply the nominal 5-sigma sensitivities for each band -- as described above, we expect to detect most objects in all bands with S/N>5.
Our targets are selected using the measured far-infrared fluxes (65 micron~Akari or 60 micron~IRAS fluxes, F(60mu) and the expected ratios of the mm-wave to far-IR micron flux, to give expected 3mm, 1.3 mm, and 0.88mm fluxes greater than or equal to 0.25, 2, and 5 mJy, respectively. The values of the expected ratios and emissivity power-law index used in our estimation is based on our existing results of bright far-IR objects detected with interferometers like the SMA or CARMA.
We have selected sources to cluster within groups such that all sources within a group are located within a circle of 10 deg on the sky. Hence, for each of these groups, one calibration/pointing sequence will suffice. Taking into account the on-source integration times, and the calibration/pointing times for each band separately, we find that we will need a total time of 1.34 hr per group for all 3 bands.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: g4 3 mm continuum emission in postAGB objects to search for very large grains

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen each of the fours SPWs with the widest bandpass available (1875 MHz), and the lowest spectral resolution (as we are only interested in continuum detection), avoiding frequency overlaps and maximizing sensitivity. We have carefully chosen center frequencies in each of the bands 3, 6, and 7 in order to minimize overlap of the bandpass with telluric lines. The frequency ranges covered in bands 3, 6, and 7 are 90-105, 223-243, and 336-351 GHz.

Our existing observations of a small sample of pAGB sources show that the continuum emission is likely to be compact (<~1"). But we do not know the extent or the structure of the emitting region on smaller scales. There are several possibilities - e.g., the emission could be confined to an unresolved structure at the highest resolution (e.g. a ~100 AU disk); or it could be an extended equatorial torus structure (~1000-2000 AU at typical distance of 2 kpc, i.e., 0.5"-1" in size) as seen in scattered light in HST images of PPNe, or it could be a combination of such a structure and emission from dense regions at the base of the bipolar lobes.
We aim to resolve the mm-wave continuum emission if its size is greater than the beam size, i.e., >0.35" (and provide significant constraints for models if it is smaller). Our choice of an angular resolution of 0.35" (about 1000 AU at 3 kpc) has been made in order to allow for the possibility to distinguish between the relatively compact disks expected in dpAGB objects (<1000 AU) and the more extended ones of size ~1000-2000 AU expected for PPNe, at a typical distance of 3 kpc. Since our target list includes many sources significantly brighter than the threshold flux values for inclusion in the list, for these we expect to obtain high dynamic range images at the highest frequency, that will be able to distinguish between the above possibilities.

For this band (band 3), our required sensitivity is 0.05 mJy/beam (see full explanation for all bands below).
We require fairly short on-source integration times per source(about 3.5 min, 0.5 min, 0.5 min) for bands 3, 6, and 7, respectively), and the total observing times are dominated by the calibration and pointing sequence, which requires about 25-35 min per wavelength band. We require 1-sigma sensitivities of 0.05, 0.4, 1.0 mJy/beam in Bands 3, 6, 7 (at frequencies of about 90-105, 223-243, and 336-351 GHz), which will provide high signal-to-noise (S/N) for all of our sources in each band. In the cover sheet, the fluxes provided for each source are NOT the expected fluxes, but simply the nominal 5-sigma sensitivities for each band -- as described above, we expect to detect most objects in all bands with S/N>5.
Our targets are selected using the measured far-infrared fluxes (65 micron~Akari or 60 micron~IRAS fluxes, F(60mu) and the expected ratios of the mm-wave to far-IR micron flux, to give expected 3mm, 1.3 mm, and 0.88mm fluxes greater than or equal to 0.25, 2, and 5 mJy, respectively. The values of the expected ratios and emissivity power-law index used in our estimation is based on our existing results of bright far-IR objects detected with interferometers like the SMA or CARMA.

Our targets are selected using the measured far-infrared fluxes (65 micron~Akari or 60 micron~IRAS fluxes, F(60mu) and the expected ratios of the mm-wave to far-IR micron flux, to give expected 3mm, 1.3 mm, and 0.88mm fluxes greater than or equal to 0.25, 2, and 5 mJy, respectively. The values of the expected ratios and emissivity power-law index used in our estimation is based on our existing results of bright far-IR objects detected with interferometers like the SMA or CARMA.
We have selected sources to cluster within groups such that all sources within a group are located within a circle of 10 deg on the sky. Hence, for each of these groups, one calibration/pointing sequence will suffice. Taking into account the on-source integration times, and the calibration/pointing times for each band separately, we find that we will need a total time of 1.34 hr per group for all 3 bands.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen each of the fours SPWs with the widest bandpass available (1875 MHz), and the lowest spectral resolution (as we are only interested in continuum detection), avoiding frequency overlaps and maximizing sensitivity. We have carefully chosen center frequencies in each of the bands 3, 6, and 7 in order to minimize overlap of the bandpass with telluric lines. The frequency ranges covered in bands 3, 6, and 7 are 90-105, 223-243, and 336-351 GHz.

There are several possibilities - e.g., the emission could be confined to an unresolved structure at the highest resolution (e.g. a ~100 AU disk); or it could be an extended equatorial torus structure (~1000-2000 AU at typical distance of 2 kpc, i.e., 0.5"-1" in size) as seen in scattered light in HST images of PPNe, or it could be a combination of such a structure and emission from dense regions at the base of the bipolar lobes.

For this band (band 3), our required sensitivity is 0.05 mJy/beam (see full explanation for all bands below).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The recent discovery of large mm/submm excesses in a few post-AGB objects, inferred to arise in dusty disks with large masses of mm-size dust grains provides an exciting new probe of binary processes such as Bond-Hoyle/Wind-Roche-Lobe-Overflow accretion or common-envelope ejection that have been proposed to explain the formation of dense equatorial disks in these objects. Upper limits of 2" for the sizes of a few sources rule out extended dust-shell models, showing that the dust is confined to compact structures.
This proposal focuses on multiwavelength continuum observations (from 0.87 to 3 mm) of a statistical, flux-limited sample of post-AGB objects, in order to robustly determine the dust power-law emissivity index in the mm-to-submm wavelength range that characterizes the dust grains in these objects. We will constrain the extents of the emitting regions and derive the masses of the large-grain population in these objects, allowing us to test theories for the formation of disks and torii around post-AGB stars, and to solve the mystery of how such large grains can emerge on presumably short time scales in these systems.
